Walk in to the Market. The selection of goodies here is amazing, vintage clothes, great food, arty stuff... WOW and so pretty

Interesting boho neighbourhood. Wander this maze of lovely streets to find lots of interesting bars, restaurants and shops. Difficult to navigate without a map as every street seems to look alike but well worth a detour.

One night in Jordaan. Full of great cafés and restaurants and interesting salons and galleries of wonderful and weird things. A visual delight, the place is buzzing and all set against the backdrop of beautiful canals and small winding streets. Lots of character and interesting people. So close to the centre as well.

Beautiful area of Amsterdam. Really enjoyed walking through this area. The houses and architecture is absolutely amazing. You also pass by it on the boat tours that you can take through Amsterdam. So if you have an opportunity definitely go

Lovely area of Amsterdam. Because my hotel was not far from this area, we spent quite a lot of time in the cafes, bars, shops etc. this was quite new to me even though I have been to Amsterdam many times...and I liked it a lot. A very nice discovery for me on this visit to the city.

Good walk. We enjoyed combing through the small streets. Quite a local feel with some parts looking lost in time. Bought distinctive pieces in a new shop "Brainy Days" with excellent range of random items, jewelry and leather totes and bags,, most of which were locally sourced. The find made our walk complete.
Cute & Quaint!. Stayed in this neighborhood and ate there twice. Much quieter and chic than the other parts of the city.

Very beautiful and charming. Need to visit. Look for the Winkel 43, close to a church. Best apple pie ever!
Take care to walk around without a map. Everything look so the same (houses, streets, channels, stores, etc). So I got lost some times :D

a nice walk from the Dam to Noodermarkt. I am Dutch, and sometimes a tourist in my own city,Some way some how me and my wife move on a nice somerday to the DAM, populair as a crosspoint to all kind af interresting places. The palace, red light district, some popular Shopping streets, it always nice. But i like to go a little further, from the Dam, to Nieuwe Dijk, still nice for shopping,so I will loose my wife, because she loves shopping, but i pull her out and take her with me. To the end of Nieuwe Dijk, furhter to the Haarlemmer straat. The less people, more cute shops , and restaurants. Take a coffe, some where, sit back and relax, close to a canal, enjoy some applecake or so. Then go furher, Haarlemmerstraat has some different shops, than all the big stores in the Kalverstraat. Even for a non shopper like me it is fun. Than go to Noordermarkt. It has two parts, the long market, with foods, cheese in many kinds, fresh fried fish, fresh fruit drinks. It something differend and fun. The second part is somekind of green market, and second hand, or antieks. When you tired, wel i was, time for some nice foods, in one of the sweet restaurants.If you have a mood to walk take your parner by the hand, and walke slowly true the small steets and cannals, back to,,,home, or so. I had fun, as a tourist in my own town, and most af all we had a good feeling at the end of the day.Have funT
Lovely neighbourhood. Great for walking around, pretty quiet.Make sure to have a slice of Appel pie at Winkels! Best in the world!

Best part of Amsterdam. A less touristy part of Amsterdam and extremely scenic. Still close to the centre though! Also a good way to immerce yourself in some local culture and get to meet people who live in Amsterdam.

A little village witin Amsterdam, LOVELY!. On friday evening or saturday, when the weather is good, lots of little streets are full with people sitting in front of little bars and coffeehouses. The streets are beautiful, with lots of plants and flowers. Brouse the internet for the markets that take place in that area, near the Noorderkerk, worth getting all kinds of fres tings!

One of the nicest areas of Amsterdam. Beautiful, charming, best place to stay in Amsterdam. Feels like you are part of the real Amsterdam, staying alongside the locals. We always use our bikes to get around, it's so easy to get from one side of the city to the other.
Lovely area. Expensive but very nice - beautiful individual shops and lovely people - overall a very nice place to be

A peaceful corner in a busy city. I walked around the neighbourhood, guidebook in hand, looking at the buildings/ houses and reading about the stories behind them.I think this is the way to do it. I you don't feel like walking, ride your bike from street to street. But don't do it without the information. Otherwise, it may look like an ordinary neighbourhood...but it's not!A final comment: It was one of the moments I enjoyed away from all the buzzing of the city centre, the loud tourists and the city lights. Visit the Jordaan late in the afternoon, and you won't regret it!
Favorite Area. One of the favourite days was walking through the Jordaan, It takes you to another time. We were lucky to walk during one of the sunny days and perfect weather.
My perfect Amsterdam!. Quieter but had lovely shops and restaurants. Pretty canal side cafes and bars without the noise of the more popular tourist areas. Just how I imagined Amsterdam to be.
Good area to wander. Street cafés, canals, narrow streets, typical old houses making it a good place to wander and see what you can find.

Quaint if a tad busy!. Did this area by bike and it was a real pleasure, very picturesque and I suppose the true old Amsterdam. Nice cafe's and a lovely atmosphere. A must if you visit Amsterdam. Very popular as you would expect.
Interesting Neighbourhood. Great area to explore for both interesting architecture, local scene, and shopping. It is worth strolling through for an hour or two . . .
My favourite walks: Jordaan. I liked the lively streets, cosy shops, elegance and peaceful relaxed people. Houses seemed worth living, would liike to live there myself.

I always return. It's been about a year since I was last in Amsterdam. One of the first things I did on this most recent trip was to head back to the Jordaan. It is, without question, my favorite part of the city. The architecture, shops, cafés, and views in this section of town are unsurpassed. It also contains what I consider to be the most beautiful small canal in Amsterdam - Egelantiersgracht. A visit to this beautiful city would not be complete without spending some time soaking in the Jordaan.

Perfect Neighbourhood. our reception clerk said this was the area people who live in Amsterdam want to be in. It has the 3 canals , with bars and restaurants alongsife. It has elegant houses and architecture. it has markets and locals shops. Its just perfect
Nice area for walking. One of many nice areas to walk around in. Lots of things to watch and enjoy both for camera and eyes. The famous Anna Frank House is also here.
Nice neighborhood to wonder with a bike. Jordaan is a place of houses and small buildings, a residential area. I took a bike tour that explored the area, and was very nice.
:). The best neighbourhood to wander around. Lots of little shops that aren't mainstream, nice places to have a cup of coffee, something to eat or enjoy some other specialities from the Netherland ;)

very trendy. The Jordaan is probably one of the most beautiful neighbourhoods in central Amsterdam. its worth walking through and enjoy the wonderful canals and historic architecture. The Jordaan throws one of the best celebrations on King's Day.

Great part of Amsterdam. I stayed at the Toren in this part of Amsterdam. This area is known for its restaurants and sites. The beautiful streets are littered with bars and cafes, not to mention Amsterdam's famous "coffee shops"

Grab a coffee/beer and relax at one of the cafes!. This is an adorable neighborhood filled with cafes and shops right next to the canal. It's a nice area to take a break from the center of Amsterdam and the craziness.

The Best Neighborhood in Amsterdam. My wife and I recently spent three nights in the heart of The Jordaan area in Amsterdam. I cannot say enough good things about this neighborhood. It offers beautiful canals and architecture, a lively nightlife, historical buildings and museums, and world-class people watching. There are wonderful restaurants, and a vibe much like that of Greenwich Village in New York City. It is safe, clean, and full of surprises. My wife and I got lost one night in this fantastic neighborhood, and I almost didn't want to find my way, I was having so much fun being lost there!
Wow. We went here the first day in Amsterdam and went back three times. It was so nice there! Anne Frank house, churches, canals and shopping.
The area is great.. This area is my favourite in Amsterdam. Really stunning to look at, lovely shops and cafes. A fab place to relax and enjoy the best of Amsterdam.

Great for Walking. The apartment I rented was in the heart of the Jordaan and so I spent much of my Amsterdam visit exploring the narrow streets, interesting boutiques, great restaurants and Monday open-air markets. Architecturally interesting and incredibly quiet (except during World Cup matches). The perfect area to experience Amsterdam as locals do.

Nice bars and cool atmosphere. A very nice place to have some wine at evenings. Many young locals hang around at evening time, nice music and calm atmosphere. We could have moved to more bars but could not leave the first we hanged out at, it was so relaxing and fun

Very simply- The place to stay. This area just oozes charm character and is full of locals enjoying life in this great suburb. Quiet streets with more charming canals and a fantastic selection of bars, restaurants & shops.And only a 10 min walk to the more central attractions ( Anne Franks Hse, 9 Street, Red light district, lots of museums). So close enough so that you can spend all day in town, pop 'home' relax change and pop back into town for a meal, although you can find pretty much any kind of restaurant locally from posh places booked for months, to informal placesA bunch of recommendations to eat:Donna Sofia on Anjeliersstraat (a Little Italy)- local pasta/ pizza excellent lunch there and always packed walking past at nightHostaria- another Italian almost opposite Donna S- had supper there and ut was good food at a good price with charming lady owner been there for 20 yrs.Daalder- on Lindengracht- could get in tried twice need to book well in advance for wkends but looks fabBrasserie Vlaming in Princengracht- excellent, fab night defn worth the 10 min walk from JordaanL'Invite- on Bloemgracht- couldnt get in tried hard but will visit another timeRestorante Pepe- on Westerstraat- looks average to be fair but fantastic pizza and a cheap mealAnd to work off that food, hire bikes from Bike City in Bloemgracht- dutch cyclist are nutters but is good fun and a great way to get aboutFinal tip...use AirBnB.com to book accom !
Nice place for a walk. Beautiful and quintessentially Amsterdam. It is one of the oldest quarter's of the city and is definitely worth a quick walk or bike ride.

Nice Area,Shops are expensive. The area is full of small boutique shops that stock some very quaint items..................at a cost. There was not any deals to be had, but it was anice day to have a stroll around.

Great place. The atmosphere of this area is hard to describe. Cosy bars, fantastic quaint shops, delicious restaraunts. Narrow streets meandering to craftsman/women's studios. Unbelievable place to stay....

Stroll, stop, eat, sleep and enjoy. The hustle and bustle of this place is amazing!Take in an early weekend morning and enjoy the waking of a city and tapping of market stalls.Come here for the Royal celebrations (Kings Day now) at the end of April and you’ll see an ocean of orange with live bands, music and dancing.Boutique cafes, bars, restaurants and shops the whole year round this really is the place to visit in Amsterdam.

Perfect. Take a stroll around the Jordaan area just simply to get a feel for the friendly, local atmosphere, and the beautiful houses, gardens and surroundings. Great little local cafes on practically each corner add to this area's charm. I'd live here if I could!

NIce quiet neighborhood to walk around in.. Rick Steves has a free android app with a walking tour of this neighborhood. Use this app to get there and learn some facts then just walk around the canals and enjoy

Beautiful Neighborhood. This is a beautiful neighborhood in Amsterdam, full of lovely cafes, restaurants and restaurants. It feels very far away from the craziness of Central Station and Dam Square. We loved walking all around Jordaan, day and night.

Genuine Amsterdam. This area is very old Amsterdam in my opinion, nice area that isn't ruined with modern design. I think it's a wonderful area to visit. Lots of places to eat and chill out while people watching.
Lovely area.. This is a lovely area which is well worth exploring. As well as being a residential area there are plenty of shops and cafes.

Photo on every corner. That typical Amsterdam view of a long canal with a bridge in the distance covered in bikes and flowers? Well the Jordaan is that image on every corner. Cafes, bars and restaurants everywhere!

Beautiful area!!!. The Jordaan is what one imagines a trip to Amsterdam to be. We booked an apt. right in the heart of the Jordaan and loved it! Great atmosphere, fantastic restaurants & shops and still convenient to Centraal Station, public transportation and all the sights.

A pleasant area. We went for a walk around the Jordaan district on a Monday morning, a very quiet time. Many of the streets are residential and also not accessible to motor vehicles, they have lots of plants in tubs and boxes and it is altogether a very pleasant area away from the main stream area of the city. There are pleasant areas of canal and it is less than ten minutes from the Central Station.It helped us to re-charge after being with so many people for several days. We found one or two cafes on the edge of the area to get a coffee and snack.

To be Discovered.... One of the countless authentic districts of Amsterdam, The Jordaan is on a walking distance from Central Station.With its cafes, local and ethnic restaurants and nice little shops, The Jordaan is for sure one of the coolest destinations that you should cover during your Amsterdam trip.Enjoy...

A walk through old town Amsterdam. On the advice of our hotel operator, my wife and I decided to take a walk through the Jordaan district. It was a wonderful experience and a great tip to see Amsterdam as it once was. Our walk through the district was punctuated with snacks, interesting shops, and life as the locals live it. Our best meal of the day was a simple sandwich of a bun filled with locally made cheese, one that we saw a local purchase in a small cheese shop and an order we copies. A neat experience walking through Jordaan munching on one of the best lunches during our stay. A highly recommended change from seeing touristy Amsterdam to a life lived by the locals

Walked round here on Kings day, great area. Really lovely area of Amsterdam, a short walk from central station and full of great shops and cafés and restaurants. Has a great feeling of the real Amsterdam.

Great architecture BUT filthy dirty. Enjoyed walking around this district looking at all the fabulous architecture BUT unfortunately as with all of Amsterdam it was filthy dirty with food rubbish everywhere.It really is surprising that the people of Amsterdam are willing to live like this in such dirty streets.

Houseboat in Jordaan. We stayed on a houseboat in the Jordaan area for three days in November. It is a very nice area to walk. We used a laundermat and ate at several different resturants close by. There was a farmers market nearby on Saturday. We walked everywhere.
A lovely area to wander around. Walk around, stop at a sidewalk cafe, just enjoy the area. It is a lovely neighborhood to spend time in.
Great shopping. Lovely cafes. Don't miss Exota for funky vintage style clothes and Tilka for great jewellry and Mexican gear (especially if you're into Frida Kahlo!)

Don't bother. During my patents and my 5 night stay in Amsterdam last week, we followed a walking tour round the Jordaan because all of our guidebooks raved about it. Don't bother, it's not worth it. For 'bohemian', read shabby!

strol through the Jordaan. Walked around The Jordaan a couple of times during our visit to Amsterdam, just wander off the main canals & find small bars serving snacks & good beers, pick out one overlooking canal & enjoy sharing snacks while watching world go bye. Cheese museum & Tulip museum worth a visit. Don't forget to visit Anne Franke house book on line to avoid the long waiting times. This is the place to go to relax.
Jordaan district. great area if you just want to wander about take in the sights and sounds and have a multitude to places to eat or just have a drink, a friendly relaxed atmosphere

Peacefull Area with Lots Happening. Our hotel was located here so we spent a lot of time just walking around. It's just outside the hustle and bustle but not to far. Lots of cafes and small bars. Very nice residential streets to walk down here, with cute little benches and pretty flowers everywhere.A very beautiful area.

Quirky Amsterdam. Close to the Westerkerk (site of Rembrandts unmarked grave is the district known as Jordaan,which is a maze of narrow streets and tiny canala.The streets contain dozens of quirky shops selling virtually anything you could think of.The area also contains many tiny houses built for workers in the 17th Century,when Amsterdam was expanding rapidly.The area is also very close to Anne Franks house,where she and her family lived in an upstairs apartment,hiding from the Germans during part of World War Two.

Prettiest area of Amsterdam. Highly recommend staying in this area - peaceful walks next to the canals yet close to Central Station and access to all major sights. Loads of great cafes including the best apple cake at Winkels cafe next to the market..

Nice place to wander. My wife and I were in this area 3 or 4 times during our stay in Amsterdam. The area is clean and quiet for the most part . There are some streets with restaurants,cafe's and shops and some that are just residential . Very nice area to just wander around and maybe get lost and find something new.Give it a try and I'm sure you won't be disappointed

Great restaurants. Good night life and good restaurants. Beautifull place to get lost and just walk without much aim. Enjoy a sunny day at the Jordan...it is out of the rift-raft of the busyness of the Dam.
A lovely stroll.. Spent a lovely afternoon strolling around Jordaan. Lovely little one off shops. Many cafés to sit and watch the world go by.

Small Canals and Narrow Streets. We enjoyed walking around this area. There are a number of small cafes. Take a break along your walk and stop and have a coffee or beer or a nice glass of wine and soak up the atmosphere.
Lovely to wander.. We'll worth a visit and wander as there are some beautiful shops along the way. Just loved it. Some artisan shops mixed amongst cafés and stunning buildings so take your camera.

The only place to stay in Amsterdam!. I wish I knew how nice this little area is. I would have tried harder to find a hotel in this neighborhood. This place is close to the city center that you can walk there. It's a nice stroll to the Centraal Station and the houses along the canals are beautiful and charming. There are many cute shops and restaurants but it's away from most crazy tourist activities in the city center. I really regret not staying in this area but at least now I know where to stay the next time I come!
Lovely neighbourhood. A lovely leafy neighbourhood with nice canal homes lots of people living in canal boats and flowers and plants everywhere

Sweet neighborhood. Great pancakes, mint tea, restaurants and pubs. Lovely, quiet neighborhood.We enjoyed several strolls, sitting by the canals sipping coffee and people watching. Friendly folks as well.
Great, worth to see. Really nice place, if you have an hour for relaxing walk, go ahead. Jordaan is great since it's far more quite than De Wallen.

The True Authentic Amsterdam. This area is one of the nicest area in Amsterdam away from the touristy Dam Square and Chinatown. It is really peaceful and quiet filled with nice café, antique and book stores and residence houses with nice architecture. One can just spent an entire afternoon just slowly strolling around enjoying the peace and the canal view. I have been here 3 times and hope to be able to come here as often as I can. It is really beautiful.

beautiful area. this must be the nicest area in all of amsterdam. Has a lovely relaxed feel about the place. the nine streets (negen straatjes) in particuilar was really nice with lovely boutiques and vintage shops with some lovely pavement cafes and bakery shops selling mouthwatering cakes and pastries, yummy.

The quiet and classy part of Amsterdam. The Jordaan district is a refreshing change of pace from the hectic world of the train station, red light district, Dam square, etc. This is a neighborhood with lovely houses and quaint boutiques and some elegant restaurants.

Houseboat gardens!. It takes a beautiful afternoon to stroll through Jordaans streets and take in the sights. It is extremely charming and beautiful, with flowers and picturesque canals everywhere. I think the area is best enjoyed by foot, stopping at the various cafes and shops which are surprisingly cheap. Stay away from the bike paths, it helps to look left and right many times before running across the road because bikes appear out of nowhere.
Home from Home. We stayed here for a week and it is brilliant! Like another world, Quite unique. 50 word requirement again - just go and walk around if you're not staying.
Great area to walk or bike. rest quieter area of Amsterdam to bike around. We really enjoyed grabbing dinner and eating along one of the canals.

nice. you can walk to this location. it is where the Ann Frank house is located. We didn't want to pay and stand in line to go and see the inside so we just walked to it, took a picture outside. Nice beautiful day, no need to go and spend it standing in line to go see a house!!
Café Nol. ....for a relaxing night with the locals in the Jordaan! We had a great time singing along with the Dutch songs and we blended in with the locals without any problems.

Lovely and leafy. This is our favourite area of Amsterdam. It is very pretty with lovely houses and shops and surprisingly leafy. There is a great buzz to the place but without all the tackiness of the RLD or other parts of Amsterdam. We have stayed in apartments here twice and really like this area.

Old Amsterdam. The best thing to do to see this area is to have your walking shoes on and do lots of exploring. There are so many interesting artistic shops and old pubs. Go in and experience a cafe with different culture and art. The Jordan started back in the 1700 and is very historical. Look at the old buildings especially up the top and the shape. Love this area for different cafés and artistic venues.

Serene. We cycled through this area as a part of our bike tour. It's really beautiful with some nice cafes and some great history. If you're sick of the bustle of the Red Light District, wander the streets here for a bit and relax next to a canal.

Welcome to our homes!. The Jordaan is a great place to wander, stroll, walk around. At every corner you'll find little shops, coffee places and every 10 steps you take there's another great old building. Best thing: This is where we live! So you'll encounter many locals in all the shapes and forms we come in. Welcome to our homes!

A night out. Stumbled upon this part of town because of the theater .Very nice ,fine dining at Restaurant Chow ,great experience and entertainment . It was all very pleasant .prices were good ,service was excellent .i enjoyed boom Chicago ,I also had a late meal at Wasie Thai restaurant near the canal ,the owner Walter was a fantastic host .even though it was quiet late ,he was pure hospitable!mFresh food cooked in front of you ,great service and totally cheap!

Wish had more time. What a charming and quaint place to visit from hassle of Amsterdam. We took canal cruise hop on hop off and took time to explore Jordan. Lots of cafes, interesting shops, architecture.Found it a very romantic place to be and finished our exploring at one of the restaurants overlooking canal..

Great Neighborhood for a stroll. Amsterdam is above all a city for walking. With its network of canals and beautiful quiet side streets, the Jordaan area is a wonderful place to spend several hours just taking in the architecture and the shops and when you get tired..canal side cafés. Herengracht,Prinsengracht with their small bridges and beautiful homes provide a nice respite from the lines and crowds of the rijks and Van Gogh museums and Dam Square. Enjoy the quiet and beauty of this area but make sure to stay off the bike paths!! U less you are prepared for a stern warning from a speeding cyclist.

Relaxing Walk. It is basically a residential area with lots of restaurants bars and independent small shops. It is pretty and interesting and a nice change from the very touristy areas of Amsterdam. Worth spending some time for a relaxing walk.

beautiful neighborhood to stay and explore. we stayed in the jordaan on our recent visit to amsterdam, and rarely left the neighborhood. it was beautiful to stroll the charming streets and over the many beautiful canals. there are also many shops and cafes.highly recommended

A lovely place to stroll on a sunny day. We bought the Jordaan walking tour brochure from the tourist office and did a self-guided stroll around the neighbourhood. It is a very pretty area with lovely old buildings, nice little cafes/restaurants and interesting shops. A nice thing to do on a sunny day when you are tired of museums and churches.

My favourite part of Amsterdam. Although we have been to Amsterdam several times we have never ventured in to the Jordaan area and it is now my favourite area in Amsterdam! We did a self guided walk from Frommers which gives you a really good introduction of the area, and took us to places that we would never have found ourselves such as hidden gardens and courtyards which were hidden behind unassuming gates.The area has a village feel to it, very few tourists and it is where people live so you see everyone going about their everyday business. We visited on a Saturday and came across two interesting markets selling everything from Cheese and sausages to books and antiques!The architecture is amazing and worth just wandering around taking it all in. There are lots of little neighbourhood cafes throughout the area to stop for a drink or lunch.
The most beautiful district of Amsterdam. Its delightful to visit and get lost around those streets. You cant go to Amsterdam and skip a walk in the Jordaan district. Mandatory.
Little charming streets.. A lot of good shops, restaurants, beautiful people, nice views, good for a biking tour. The view of the canals, the cafés, everything so nice, it so refreshing and relaxing,

Lose a few hours here.... This is a beautiful part of the City. The architecture is stunning and amazingly clean and maintained; so much so it's easy to forget how old the buildings are. It's a perfect spot to wander around and the variety in the buildings and the unique touches and features on may of them make this very interesting and plenty of bars/restaurants, shops and markets to add to the experience.Beautiful!
Jordaan Walk. Great local neighborhood away from tourists. Great walk-thru with neighborhood shops and eateries. One of our favorites while visiting Amsterdam.
Nice area. Just like most of Amsterdam the houses are very pretty. This area seemed to also have lots of flowers around ... Nice.

Leafy Neighbourhood :) :) Great pubs. Well worth taking the time out from the coffeeshops and red light to rub shoulders with the locals and sip dutch beer on the side of the canals. If the weather is good its perfect to stroll around for an afternoon.

Peaceful neighbourhood. Wecycled all over th city and somehow this is the most peaceful site in Amsterdam ever. Very near to the canal snd people there were very welcoming. Slightly different than the rest of of thr city. Love it!
Cool neighborhood. Great walkable neighborhood; very picturesque with lots of restaurants. Novice bike riders would do better here than in the central district.

Wonderful area to visit or stay. We stayed at a house in The Jordaan while in Amsterdam for a week. It was quiet and so picturesque. The canals were gorgeous, the steep stairs in the house made it unique to us, the feeling of being in Amsterdam was reminded to us every time we stepped outside! While Amsterdam is a really busy city, staying in The Jordaan allowed us to step away from the hustle around Amsterdam Centraal, the red light district etc. Highly recommend this neighborhood for a stay, and if not, at least for a visit!

Amsterdam's SOHO.. If you love the charming quirky side of a sophisticated city then Jordaan is for you. Pub after pub,craft shops, less expensive light lunches, great places for predinner tapas and a neighbourhood to let your hair down - visit this jeans and sneaker district, This is our second favourite neighbourhood in Amsterdam.

Interesting area. Spend time and wander this part of Amsterdam and you will find some really interesting places and shops. There are lots of antique shops though we weren't entirely sure they were real antiques and not rubbish. There are some lovely vintage dress shops.The whole area is criss crossed with picturesque canals.

Wonderful neighborhood to wander through. Quiet, lacking the volumes of tourists, this gem is where our Hotel Sebastian was located and it couldn't have been better - mostly locals in the cafes and shops, we had plaenty of dining options and wonderful strolls....Stay here if you can!
Just too cool. Think Brighton Lanes but bigger and with even better shops and the most friendly, beautiful people. Canal thrown in just to make it more gorgeous.
Great to wander around. Whe my wife and I visit Amsterdam (twice a year) we love to go around here. A really nice ambiance, great small shops, cafes and restaurants. This is real Amsterdam.
Easy to find and well worth the stroll. A quieter side of Amsterdam. Beaut cafes for coffee and cake. Interesting architecture. Easy to walk around and just take it all in.
Cosmo food and shopping. Easily located near other attractions well worth a visit. Wide variety of food and eclectic shops. Note some shops don't take cash only cards!

impressive Neighborhood. It is "the" place in Amsterdam that everyone tries to squeeze into their trip. The place is beautiful with the innovative and compact buildings all different and elegant and making a beautiful view along the canal borders. The whole neighborhood has a lot of character and with so much to see and experience, it is a must visit place.

Beautiful canals and lots of cafés, shops. One of the most beautiful areas in Amsterdam city with good photo opportunities of the canals.
Lots of cafés and vibrant atmosphere.

Sobriety in an early urban shape. It is probably the most attractive district in Amsterdam, and well deserves its reputation for sobriety and understated elegance. The nine shopping streets are well worth a visit.
An ok area.... This area was a quite little area. It is worth a little stroll through as there are many independent stores here but they can be quite pricey.

Interesting area. The Jordaan area of Amsterdam has an excellent selection of typically friendly bars and restaurants. It has the feeling of being in another village and not so busy as the tourist areas. Love it.
Plenty to see in this area. lots of places to walk around and just absorb the atmosphere, watch out for the bicycle riders & motor-cycles when crossing the roads

To bring an extraordinary souvenir from Amsterdam. Don't be fooled by the other reviews "De Negen Straatjes" or "The Nine Streets" are not in De Jordaan!! The Jordaan is the neighborhood bordered by Prinsengracht, Brouwersgracht, Lijnbaansgracht and Leidsegracht (take a look at the map of Amsterdam). Among the canals of De Jordaan, Bloemgracht and Lauriergracht are among the prettiest of the city and many of the other narrow streets offer lots of interesting things to see; just stroll around and "get lost". You may even find the 19 hidden court yards behind the facades: beautiful tranquil, green squares bordered by small homes that used to be for the elderly. Look here http://www.tussentaalenbeeld.nl/A60f4.htm if you can't find them by yourself (page is in Dutch but you'll figure the street addresses, just look them up in Google maps). De Jordaan is great for shopping too. Avoid the souvenir shops around Dam and Central Station and get yourself something truly unique from one of the many quirky shops in De Jordaan. And don't forget to visit the food market on Saturdays (Lindengracht) for superb fresh fish, fruits, nuts, bread and veggies, and if you are into it the organic food market on Noordermarkt, also on Saturdays. On Monday mornings there is a street market on Westerstraat; you may find a cool hand bag there or some vintage fashion. Among the many restaurants and bars there is something for everyone. There are over 240 restaurants in De Jordaan, just look here at Tripadvisor. And after dinner, walk over to the Tweede Anjeliersdwarsstraat where Monte Pelmo makes the best ice cream of Amsterdam.

The best neighbourhood in Amsterdam. The ''Jordaan" is the best, most interesting and charming neighbourhood in Amsterdam. It has a great atmosphere with its small canals and its numerous small 'brown' cafe's (real cafe's to have a drink).For any visitor this is highly recommendable and I do not only say this because my roots are here with my father and grand-father living and growing up there!
typical Holland. taste the true Amsterdam in this old quarter close to the canals within the famous Dutch "grachtengordel." Nice restaurant and the famous Dutch bars.

the best place to be in Amsterdam. It's the most beautiful place of amsterdam.
There are pub's, store about everyting you want to bay it

Best area in Amsterdam. We loved the area... best restaurants, best bars, nice bridges... perfect place to locate!
All important places to visit are very close and is nice to walk around.. and safe too.
Cafes. Little area around the canals by Anne Frank house, very pleasant atmosphere lots of little cafes great place to chill.

Great Ambiance. The place with its tiny alleys , whole bunch of restaurants and shops makes one good of a place to take a stroll and feel the pure and true air of this beautiful city. The views are amazing and Jordaan is actually the best place to stay in Amsterdam with so many options in stay, dining and shopping and more than that there is also the opportunity to feel the local and true Amsterdam-ian vibe. Loved the place and I think this is one place which was frequented by me and my friends.

Shopping heaven. I could have spent all three days of my trip in this area alone wandering through it's myriad shops and boutiques. Retro, antiques, clothing, art galleries and fabulous tea and cake at the corner cafes.

Nicest part of Amsterdam. Not too touristy (as long as you avoid the Nine Streets). Explore the canals on the western side of the Prinsengracht, and on Saturday the market around the Noordkerk is simply fabulous.
The best. Just the best place to stay in Amsterdam. Stayed here many times. Wonderful ambiance, lots of chill, nice people, perfect! Nothing else to say really...
Cool neighborhood. The Jordaan is a very pretty area. It has a lot of great restaurants, cafes and bars. My husband and I spent most of our time in this neighborhood.
Interesting. Great area for wandering around. Plenty of shops, cafés and restaurants. The Nine Streets are especially good.
Best area in Amsterdam. This was the best part of Amsterdam, authentic, quite, friendly and picturesque, I could spend hours and hours in a bar here watching the world go by. amazing !

Amsterdamish. Love this part of the city.I have spent only 3 days in Amsterdam, and my staying was trying to see lots of places for not so much time. What I have notices for few hours spent there is that there were less noice than around Dam Square... The architecture is similar with all those beautiful tall and narrow houses, many cafes and bars.

A Terrific Neighborhood. This neighborhood is a real find. Lots of really cute shops, cafes and restaurants. Many squares and parks where you can sit and people watch while having a beer. One particularly upscale supermarket which is worth browsing through.It has a comfortable and uncrowded feeling, and is a nice respite from the center of Amsterdam.Definitely worth checking out.

Absolutely amazing area!. Go here, get lost and walk around for hours!This is what a city vacation is all about and once you're lost small pubs, cafés and boutiques will pop up!As soon as you get out your map someone will come along and help you on your way! Everything's in a nicer pace here!
lovely place to wander away from trams. pretty shutters on most of the homes but so quiet no trams or cyclists loved this area the most very nice friendly people about too everyone smiles loved it
Great place to walk.. Lovely little pubs to stop at and take in the atmosphere. Great for a nice sunday afternoon walk but not too much open.

Great area to stay. Have spent seven days here, in Jordaan, in a very comfortable airbnb. Terrific area, close to so many cafés, restaurants, trams, supermarkets.... All you could want. Easy walk or bike ride to so many Amsterdam attractions. Similar feel to the Marais area of Paris, but not as hectic. Will stay here again when we return to Amsterdam.

Great neighbourhood. I've visited Amsterdam many times but this was the first that I stayed in this area. The streets are lined with trendy boutiques and great restaurants and cafes. There's a really good ambience walking around here and there's no shortage of eateries to book in to. The shops are a mix of independent and designer and there's something to be found for everyone. I really enjoyed having this area as my base - it felt safe at night and there wasn't too much noise as the restuarants and bars seemed to close around or before midnight. It's less than 1k to Dam Sq so really central location too.

Great place to stay, if you get the chance.. A perfect location for getting into the centre of town and for taking a stroll to museums, shops, bars and restaurants. With such speedy tram links, nothing is very far away. We were lucky enough to be based on the Jordaan for our weekend swap in Amsterdam and would definitely recommend it.

Best Neighborhood for Dining. We stayed in Amsterdam for 3 days and made a point to eat in this neighborhood every night. There are noticeably less tourists in this area and after a long day of sight seeing it was nice to chill at a restaurant with more locals than loud tourists. Great views of the canals as well.

best area in Amsterdam. I really advise everyone who comes to Amsterdam to go to the Jordaan area which is close to the city center. Here you can find real Amsterdam with small streets, different unusual shops, traditional Dutch houses. Its really great area. the best thing is to walk here and try to get lost in the streets..

Sirenic. My most lasting impression of Amsterdam is wandering around The Jordaan at my leisure. It is like slipping into another time, with its well-preserved buildings and slow, relaxed atmosphere and beautiful canals. It is definitely one of the quiter parts of Amsterdam, and a walk around here is relaxing after a busy day in the more popular areas. It is dotted with small restaurants, cafés and the odd coffeeshop, all of which just seem to suit the place perfectly. I still dream about The Jordaan.
Chelsea in Amsterdam. We loved it! Quirky, quiet, green and with plenty of choice of boutique shops, bars and restaurants away from the madding tourist crowd.
Lovely strolling and shopping quarter. You can find streets here that are not full of tourists, plus interesting shops, cafe's, and restaurants. We went back several times during our three day stay.

Charming area. If you enjoy small shopping boutiques, at reasonable prices, this is the area to go. You can spend an afternoon just wandering around this neighborhood, stopping at any one of the many cafés along the way to eat, drink or just people watch.
Heart of Holland. This is my favourite area within the city! The quaint bakaries, bars and beautiful canals will give you a truly authentic experience of beautiful Amsterdam. Highly recommended.
Great Area. Wonderful location to stay, great locality, restaurants, coffee stops, bas canals and away from the bustle.

Jardaan Jewel. NO tourists just locals. How refreshing it was to stroll through this peaceful and surprisingly beautiful part of Amsterdam. Lovely local restaurants and coffee shops offer just the respite you need from all the busy days of sightseeing.
Great neighborhood. This is one of the best neighborhoods in Amsterdam to stay, wander, or enjoy bakeries and cafes. This a more upscale area of town and has beautifully kept homes to look through.

Jordaan is keeping it's charm. This traditional neighbourhood of Amsterdam is keeping it's charm. Just stroll around the streets and sit down on outside terrace and watch the crowd passing by. Have a biet at one the localk restaurants and enjoy the views over the Westerkerk

Most beautiful sophisticated area. This is definitely the most beautiful part of Amsterdam I experienced. The atmosphere are relaxed, and there are not that many tourists. Lots of galleries and everything is very sophisticated.

Excellent area to relax and enjoy the city. Very nice area to hang around, relax and enjoy the city in a café or outdoor restaurant. Easy to walk through the area with many shops and outdoor cafes. The attractions are also good to see with the Anne Frank Museum as the main attraction.

Must visit. This is just a street but it has deep Amsterdam roots. The people who are originally from this area are considered to be very authentic Amsterdammers.
From originally a low class area it is now converted to a very up-scale neighbourhood. The main street is full of tradition, cozy bars and restaurants. Not to be missed when visiting Amsterdam

Enjoy "Old Town" Amsterdam. Our B&B was in The Jordaan area. The area has canals, small shops, bars, restaurants, etc. This is the "old" part of Amsterdam and is quite quaint. While there were many tourists the area itself is not touristy. My recommendation is to take a canal tour (by boat), enjoy a beverage outside while people watching, and just enjoy the life of The Jordaan. One word of caution, the cyclists are crazy--keep your eyes open and be safe.

Favorite neighborhood. Lovely streets, mixture of old and very tasteful modern, great restaurants, fun shops, studios, lots of unexpected finds. Despite rising rents its working class and neighborhood character still comes through.
Go here. Fun shops of all sorts. The historic value of the the architecture is wonderful with lots of opportunity to take pictures.

Best District in Amsterdam. We loved the quieter streets and canals in the Jordaan. There are some lovely little restaurants, cafes and quirky shops and it is a nice place to wander about. Flowers are lovely at this time of year.
A must to walk around on a fine day. Very interesting area bounded by canals with loads of small shops and cafes. Stop off and sit outside weather permitting while doing some quirky shopping.

My favorite part of Amsterdam. I think that it's a shame that so many visitors to the city stay in the Dam/kalverstraat/RedLightDistrict/Rembrandtsplein strip. There is so much more to see of the city. I love simply wandering this neighborhood. It has some of the most relaxed cafes in the city and interesting window shopping.
A must. You just have to walk there. Its a must. The atmosphere is very nice to hang around, get something to eat and drink.
A Bohemian Paradise. What a lovely area! Very laid back & full of lovely cafes, bars, restaurants etc. Busy yet a peaceful, chilled out place,

Plenty of Cafes and shops - the real amsterdam. We walked around Jordaan for ages, I thoroughly recommend it to anyone. Most of the streets are filled with small jewellery stores or small cafes filled with locals. You don't find many large businesses or chains in this part of town and the wares on sale are very unique and inspiring. We loved walking around here, looking in windows and imaging living in this part of the town. Definitely a must-do for anyone going to Amsterdam!
Lovely relaxed area. Altogether in my opinion the very best locality to stay in Amsterdam.We stay approx 200 mtres from Anne Franks house and most attractions were within walking distance.

Don't miss this part of Amsterdam!. So many delightful, small artisan shops can be found in this old district. Everything from natural soap, ceramics, interior design objects, leather goods, jewellery, sculpture, art works, stationary...You can also find interesting cafes, bread shops, flower shops.

great for window shopping and people watching. Take a break from sight seeing and do a bit of window shopping in this lovely section of Amsterdam. My husband was delighted with the Carhardt store where he bought a fashion forward jacket in dark blue - hard to believe they make work clothes in the USA! Look for the shop that sells ONLY tooth related items - brushes, pastes, etc. Do not expect to find small clothing sizes here - my daughter is an lithe thing and the Dutch are a bigger build. there are many restaurants and coffee shops too in the area.

Great place. This is the real Amsterdam...give the Damrak a miss, great atmosphere with real amsterdammers! Nice little bars and cafes next to the canals, avoid the Haarlemstraat if your not keen on crowds! Brouwergracht is the place to go!

AN OLDIE BUT GOODIE!. The Jordan in Amsterdam is the oldest part of the city. It is also the most picturesque, a great neighborhood to explore, have a meal, really get the feel of Amsterdam history. If your time is limited, skip the other tourist areas and concentrate here. The entire old city is a World Heritage Site but The Jordan is the neighborhood that gives this designation great meaning.

The Jordaan is where it's at in Amsterdam. Forget the Coffeeshops and the Red Light District, the Jordaan is where it's at in Amsterdam!Many travel guides say that this is arguably the prettiest and most romantic area of Amsterdam and I have to agree. The houses are either on streets facing canals or on pretty little cobblestone-paved alleys. The buildings were old, some of them going back to the 1600’s, and they were all pretty uniform in terms of height and style (loft style, no more than five floors each), but they were all unique as well in terms of doors and windows and brick-colour, and they were all so, so lovely to look at. It is very hard to explain the feeling of tranquility you feel walking the streets of Jordaan. Every hour, you hear the church bells from afar, hundreds upon hundreds of bikes pass you on the street, and their little boats and boat houses floated gently on their canals. On almost every corner was a little café where locals gathered to drink beer or wine, and on some corners there were coffeeshops where the smell of marijuana wafted out the door and into the street. We spent hours going up and down every street and bridge and back-alley we could find. I could easily spend a couple of days just walking around this area.
Well worth a visit. We really liked this part of the city. It is a more down-to-earth district and has a distinct and appealing character.

One of the most beautiful districts in the world.. I like to think I'm fairly well-travelled, and I think De Jordaan is one of the most beautiful district in the whole wide world. With its 16th century brick stone homes and classy population, this is the right place to relax and have some food for the eye.

Wonderful. Great to wonder about walking or cycling in a sunny day. Boho chic atmosphere by the canals. Lots of terraces, balance between Notting Hill crowd meets arty Soho with some of the Marais chic.

Adorable Neighborhood. Home of the Negen Straatjes, spending a whole day walking around the Jordaan can hardly be a waste for those interested in an Amsterdam experience outside the Red Light District. Great shopping area, you'll find a lot of interesting unique, interesting shops. If you happen to visit during a rare sunny day in the Lowlands, I highly recommend a mini picnic by one of the canals. You can even buy a cup of coffee and sit while watching the boats pass by, I promise it will be worth it!

Excellent area for a stroll, a coffee and a cake. Quiet streets, interesting architecture, different shops and even a few artisan's workshops - add a sunny day and what's not to like? Add in some good cafes and its a great area to pass half a day wandering around.

Download the App. My son downloaded the Tripadvisor App for Amsterdam, which had a "Courtyard Tour" around The Jordaan. We saw hidden courtyards open to the public but not well publicised. Also great places to stop for lunch or snacks.

One of my favorite neighborhoods in Amsterdam. It wasn't until our second day that we explored Jordaan. It was my favorite with all the outdoor music and cafes with tables outside for listening. It still had the crowds but the shops were a little more interesting and the food was great. We had no problem figuring the trams to get there.

A village feeling in Amsterdam!. Great place for a stroll, not too crowded, still many cafés and terraces and interesting architecture, showing in an excellent way how the Jordaan has been and still is!

Not to be missed. This shouldn't be too difficult to sum up. You can't go to Amsterdam without visiting Jordaan. Jordaan is a mecca for excellent cafes (great coffee and cakes), shopping and galleries. Sit outside and watch the countless locals go by on their bikes. You don't feel touristy sitting here and it feels more local than anything else. Jordaan is pretty central and easy to find, and to navigate you simply walk around the grid pattern. It definitely feels like the Greenwich Village of Amsterdam.
authentic neighbourhood. A very nice and authentic neighbourhood. While the city center is crowded with tourists, here you can feel the Amsterdam's spirit.A traveller would choose to visit this one.

Classic Amsterdam. This is a great area of Amsterdam, lots of tourists but also Amsterdam residents going about their work and play. Lots of interesting shops and plenty of places to get food and drink of all sorts. A little less of the smokers' coffee shops and red light appeal in this area.

Beautiful part of the City. this is the old part of the city. We toured it by bike which I felt was a nice way to see the area , streets and canals. The architechture was great. We had a guide which was helpful to see the differences in the buldings and style.

Awesome, charming little shopping area. Located close to Anne Frank house this is a great little area for boutique shopping , outdoor cafe's and people watching. A few good cheese shops in that area as well.
interesting place. wonderful to walk around, see the cute little houses, go into the different shops, see so many stylisch things
Great area. Excellent location . Very close to all the main attractions but away from the crowds. Great cafes and restaurants

Calm and near everything. First it started with a visit , now I live here.
Peaceful but just minutes away by bike from the center.
Small and old apartments but with the view over the channel is unforgettable.

Quaint. Amsterdam's prettiest area: Jordaan, part of the historic center of the city, and an UNESCO World Heritage site. Great shopping in the 9 Streets, but don't forget to look at the stunning architecture.

Favorite area of Amsterdam. Very pretty area with canals, bridges, flowers, fantastic old buildings. The area is much less crowded with tourists, and the cafes and restaurants still visited by (some) locals. My recommendation is just walk around, get lost and suck in atmosphere and pleasant smells from flowers, but sometimes also less pleasant smells from the cafe houses.
The best area in Amsterdam.. I really liked this area. the streets , canals , restaurants etc. This place is good for a walking tour. I like roaming around such areas.
Worth a Stroll Through. This a a bohemian area and worth a stroll through, check out tge shops and restaurants. The locals pronounce jordaan with a y.

A quiet district of Amserdam. We used the DK guide book which provided a walk lasting two hours around the Jordaan District. Lovely buildings, quiet back streets, some great cafes and bars and vibrant shopping area at the northern end. It is well worth crossing the railways via the tunnel to see the western islands where many warehouses were built and some lovely bridges. We saw a yellow submarine too!

Great bars and restaurants. We really liked this area. It seemed to be the place that locals choose to go to. We found a cosy little Chinese and also a lovely old bar with cosy, dark wallpaper and rugs for tablecloths! Lovely generous measures of vodka!!!
Lovely Area. This is the most beautiful area in Amsterdam. We rented an apartment here and enjoyed the relaxed ambiance of this area. Unique cafes and shops, Nine Little Streets, picturesque canals.

lovely. Firstly, watch out for the BIKES...Crazy. I love this area for the sheer diversity of things found here. Sex, drugs and rock and roll come to mind. The canals are just lovely. We wandered around here without a care in the world. We felt totally safe and enjoyed everything about this area. Please do visit if you are going to Amsterdam. Just fun, interesting and embrace it cos you will see all sorts of wonderful quirky things here. Love it.

Atmosphere by the canal-load. This is an excellent neighbourhood to wander around, day and night - though there are some sights in red-lit windows on stylish main streets beside the canals you'll almost certainly not want your younger kids to see. There are numerous 'brown cafes', bars, restaurants and shops to linger in and at night the lit-up canal bridges look beautiful. It's an artistic and (seemingly) thoroughly safe area, quiet and inviting. It's my favourite neighbourhood as a first-time visitor to the city.
Nicest area. A lovely part of Amsterdam,9 streets of quirky classy .shops and cafes all crisscrossing the canals.Perfect for strolling around.
My favourite area. Get away from the maddening crowd and escape into the jordaan area!! Lovely shops and restaurants where the locals go and prices are lower than around the centre of town.

A great area to stay. Having rented a unit in this area I realised its a great area to stay. Its far enough out of city not to be too touristy but close enough to easily walk to Dam Square. It has great access via the Tram system to central and also along the edge of the canals. Its great to walk amongst the main canals.
Great area. Lovely area to walk through , great architecture , nice ambience , but as with all of Amsterdam , you have to watch out for the cyclists
Great area. Lovely shopping and dining area. A must for those who prefer atmosphere and genuine experience. You can walk around for hours so bring comfortable shoes.
Not bad but. Not great either. Looks like the rest of Amsterdam. Less crowded though, a big plus for that. And no smell of you-know-what :-)
Lovely - a place to chill. Head out to the Jordaan and relax at a nice little bar with cheese and sausage. It all becomes a bit repetitive after a while so allow just one day for this.

A lovely village in a city. Jordaan is a delight. It's a kind of Islington (London) of the 90's or perhaps present day Clapham, where beer-loving locals smoke and chat with beer/wine loving arty folk with disposable income and designer glasses. It's delight to just wonder the pretty streets with rampant flowers and climbers on every other wall and coffe houses and restaurants wherever you look.Then there is the modern housing Jordaan which is not quite so pretty or well-kept. But then, that's real life and you can't just have gingerbread houses. We didn't have time to get to the market on Saturday but will do that next time.If you visit the Red Light district, then you must balance it with a trip to Jordaan for a taste of sanity and conviviality.
So Cosy. Probably one of the most lovely places to live in Amsterdam. It is very cosy and you want to stay there forever

Lovely area. I stayed in the Jordaan in August last year when visiting with my partner and loved it then, on this trip visit with my mum - the area has lots of the canals allowing for the traditional 'Amsterdam' photo's (bikes and canals!). There are also hundreds of bars and cafes, great places to sit out if the weather is good, slightly away from the hustle and bustle of Dam Square / the red light district.

LOVE!. We stayed at the Jordaan while visiting Amsterdam November of 2013 and I have to agree, after walking around the different neighborhood, the Jordaan was one of the most beautiful neighborhood! The canals, the small streets, the churches, the restaurants/cafes and the many cute little independent shops. We would love to come back to Amsterdam one day soon, stay at the Jordaan again, and enjoy a lovely spring or summer weather.
Relaxing. very relaxing and pretty part of the city, spent some time walking through here one afternoon and had some nice food
Neat area to visit. Take a stroll though here while in Amsterdam. Quiet area away from the. City centre good photo opportunities
Excelent spot. Great district! Great ambient! Nice to relax and enjoy!!One of the most beautiful parts of Amsterdam!!!!!I recommend!!
Interesting shops!. Nice quaint area to wander through when you can actually establish the roads/streets to walk around!

A lovely area to walk around. This was quite a nice and uplifting experience after the dramatic Anne Frank's house. The area has an abundance of small coffee shops, second hand shops, cute bakeries and lovely windows (Amsterdam in general has some of the most imaginative window decorations). A great way to spend a few hours just wandering about and having a glimpse at 'real' Amsterdam.

the best part of the city. Jordaan is a small and lovely neighbourhood where i wanted to spend all my time. it has a lot of cafes, bars, pubs etc which are not touristic, they are totally local! prices are reasonable.
Beautiful area to stroll around. Such a calm and lovely area with narrow streets and lovely cafés. Perfect for a stroll in look for a nice lunch.

NIce area to walk around and have a coffee with friends. The Jordaan is my favourite area from Amsterdam.It's a nice area to walk around on charming narrow streets. There are many little cafés and restaurants, nice little shops with alternative stuff and many antique shops, as well as shops that sell furniture and decoration from Asian countries. It was and still is a place where many Jews live. So, it's an area full of history and the Anne Frank's house is in the neighbourhood.During the weekends is crowded, but still interesting to visit. If you can, go to visit the Jordaan during the week, when it's still quite lively populated, but with more room in every place. A lunch and a nice walk and shop with friends during a sunny afternoon is a great program for Amsterdam. Considering that you are lucky enough to get a sunny day in the town.My favourite shop is one from a Dutch designer called Hester van Eeghen, who designs shoes and bags and has 2 shops in this Hartenstraat. The shoes I'm not that fan, but the bags are fantastic. She does different forms and uses colours very well in my opinion. Just prepare yourself for the prices, because her bags are quite expensive.

The most attractive part of Amsterdam. This was our first visit to Amsterdam and we selected one area of the city to explore for each day of our stay. We loved the little streets and small tree lined canals of he Jordaan. Although it is mainly residential there are some lovely little quirky shops and cafes. The perfect place for a stroll and absorb the real Amsterdam.
Lovely area.. Really nice area well worth a walk and a spot of lunch at one of many nice cafes. Has some good little shops as well as Anne Franks House.

Cute little neighbourhood!. This was probably one of my favourite places in Amsterdam... The neighbourhood is so cute and quaint, with nice shops and delicious restaurants around!You definitely need to check it out if you're in Amsterdam! We were here in May 2012

Quaint with lovely cafes!. The weather wasn't great when we visited but the Jordaan was very quaint and nice. We walked around for hours before dining in a small but popular local café. Had a brilliant time. Try the cheese rolls, they are yum!

Best spot to go for a Sunday morning stroll. This is such a lovely area.We spend Sunday morning here wandering the tiny side streets.You'll find some really wonderful shops here selling everything from vintage clothing to designer furniture.We got breakfast in one of the many cafes here. The atmosphere in this part of town is a cross between Greenwich Village in NYC and SOHO in London.This certainly is my favourite part of Amsterdam!
pleasant part. Jordaan is a very pleasant part of Amsterdam. Lots of small streets with nice shops and good restaurants. The people in this area are very friendly.
Favourite part of Amsterdam. We stayed next to this area. Was very beautiful, my favourite part of the city! Lost of cool stores, restaurants and coffe shops.
Greenwich village in Amsterdam. Truly what one thinks of Europe. The side streets have so many cool stores very artsy and unique shops. Shop owners so friendly and helpful

Best Place to Stay. If you have never been to Amsterdam before and are looking for a place to stay you must stay in The Jordaan area. It has lots going on. It is very artsy and has lots of cute little shops. Beautiful canals.
Very bohemian!. Good neighbourhood to wander and get yourself lost in! So much to see and do, with a very lively and friendly feel.

Jordaan and the 9 Straatjes (streets) -shopping advices. My husband and me visited Amsterdam in february 2014, we had of course bad luck with the weather, buth this fact did not lower our promenades in this vibrant and jovial parts of Amsterdam.We stayed at The Toren hotel (highly recommendeable), as it's location is next to the Jordaan, our favourite quarter in Amsterdam. I allowed myself a day of power-shopping there, as well as in the 9 streets, which are a bit more upscale, when it comes to quality and prices.The Jordaan is populated with all kind of nations, the shop owners all are extremely friendly and tremendously helpful, offer you a coffee while you shop, are always in the mood for a short or longer chat. You just could spend hours digging around and conversating with the sales people. You'll find all sorts of shops there, from vintage clothes, 2 hand shops, jewelry, antiques, curiosities and of course bags, shoes and clothes. There is literally nothing undetectable. I desperately needed a new pair of tights, the shop lady advised me competently, explained the different materials, I was so grateful for her patience and kindness.On Herenstraat I found an antique shop selling glasses, bibelot and 150-200 years old dutch silver jewelry, that is selled at such incredibly social prices (35€ for an 150 years old silver bracelet from Zeeland). Further on in that street, there is a fantastic bag shop, very expensive to our sorrow, but worth visiting.All sorts of little bistrots with terraces invite you to a break with drinks, snacks and really good coffee. Some coffee-shops (not "those" ones ;-) offer a variety of extra coffees and teas, coming from all over the world. The service is always efficient, quick and amiable.As for the 9 Straatjes, it is another shopping paradise. These streets cross Keizers-Prinsen- and Herengracht, you may so explore these great canals and in the same time discover stylish shops, a bit more exclusive as those in the Jordaan. But still: compared to my overpriced homeland or France, you make good deals. Walking over the canals and in the tiny little streets is so pleasant, the dutch people smile at you spontaneously and naturally. Coming from a country, where everyone runs around with a morose face, this was a unique experience for me and made me feel light-hearted.We had lunch in a great restaurants: the Roode Leeuw on Leliegracht. They offer a divine salad, the best in my life and fresh fish, oysters and a monster steak of 850gr. for two. My greatest wish is to find an habitation in Jordaan and live there for the rest of my life. Unfortunately I am surely not the only one, I'll add to the queue...
Best area in Amsterdam. Near the Anne frank, and if like me you want to escape the manic tourist driven City area then take a lunch or beer in a back street in the Joordan area.Classy area,
we called it the boredaan. perhaps we didn't see the Jordaan proper, but we were on bikes, so covered more ground than if on foot. Can't say there was much to shout about

Like a city within a city. The Jordaan area will be where we stay everytime we are in Amsterdam. It is so European, the people are from anywhere you can imagine in the world. Love the vibe of the Jordaan. We stayed 2 weeks in a flat on Rozenstraat in the Jordaan. You have everything you need from this area within walking distance.

don't take your car in. in the whole unesco area (center) streets are s narrow and not so good for cars. Some are really unaccessible and you end up making tours to get to the place you really want. If you are not a local you better rent a bike, or just walk because even with the bike, as a tourist you won't stop taking pictures.
Great Neighborhood. Lots of cafes, shops, artsy things to take in. Gentle vibe--lovely, not-all-restored buildings. Pleasant strolling area.

Nice for an evening stroll. Visiting the Jordaan area after a stop in a coffee shop to explore the neighborhood at night. The area was amazing to walk around and stop in for drinks and a bite to eat at the many cafes. Really picturesque area but mainly residential so don't expect a lot to do or excitement. Shops in the area seemed more like galleries with overpriced items but great area to explore.

Use Rick Steve's Audio tour!. I down loaded his audio tour and walked around per his recs. Some great info and some neat sights to see. Nice and quiet, total 180 from the red light district/marijuana scene.

Over-rated. Supposedly a hip and trendy shopping area its really just lots of pretentious shops selling stuff you can get in a charity shop for a couple of quid and selling it for stupid money. Quite picturesque in places but not really worth a special trip.

Beatutiful area. We loved the quiet streets with quirky things in the windows and just the overall feel of the area, hubby couldn't get enough pictures..
Very pleasant part of this amazing city
Must go for Amsterdam visitors. At the moment one of the most popular parts of the city. Many restaurants, bars, etc. Full of life at night. Just the place to enjoy one or the other evening.

amsterdam the city. you can not drive and park in Amsterdam, there is no parking in the city and if you find a place a full day of parking is 40 euros. one must park on the outer ring of the city and travel by bus into the inter city. parking on the ring is 8 euros a day and for only 4 days and then you must move to another parking place. the parking places are not secured and it is recommended that you buy a poster that states you have no valuables in your car. the ride into the city is from 20 to 30 minutes to the central station and then you must find transportation to you rental.

Amazing neighborhood. Walk around the city of Amsterdam is definitely very good.It don't matter if you are walking or ridding a bike.Jordaan is a calm and beautiful area and it's a pleasure walking around there.Must visit

Good, probably better in summer!. The Jordaan is a wonderful area. It's bigger than I expected so there's a bit of walking to be done but when you find a great little cafe or shop it's worth it. There are lots of lovely surprises hidden in this district. Even if you're not looking for a boutique store or organic veggie restaurant the walk itself is worth it. Beautiful buildings peer over tree lined canals, and the odd quirky painting or architecture breaks things up nicely. Worth a wander through anytime, but save your photos for the summer when the trees are in full bloom methinks. Then it's deserving of it's name (Jordaan from the french for garden)
Cultural. Interesting cultural corner of Amsterdam. Nice for strolling through with nice cafes for an afternoon rest
Not worth it. Boring streets , few shops of note, not really sure why everyone raves about this area. Waste of an hour

Not sure why this is worth visiting. We went to this area expecting to find many places for a coffee at the end of a long day. We did not find anything that was interesting. We ended up having coffee in a cold bakery!
Pretty boring. Not much to say about it really. Walked round and it was just like walking round anywhere else in the centre
A nice view of hip Amsterdam away from the tourists.. Love the boutique shops and bakeries. It is the old working class neighborhood that now boasts the wealthy.
Great quiet part of town-loved it!. Quirky, pretty, historic Jordaan-loved the Kat Kabinett and Perfumes from the Past easily reached on foot from the Dam Square or station.

A great neighborhood for a Sunday stroll!. Our family had a wonderful time exploring the shops and strolling the neighborhood. We enjoyed getting lost, finding many beautiful bridges and wonderful photo ops. We found plenty of shops to explore and cafes to consider. It was a great way to spend an afternoon after a morning of museums.
didnt find too much interesting stuff. didnt find too much interesting stuff i think you should only go here during the farmers market really

A quaint, authentic shopping district in Central Amsterdam. Walking through the Jordaan is certainly not to be missed when visiting Amsterdam. The shops, restaurants and cafes are more quaint and you are able to mingle with the locals rather than being surrounded by tourists. There are plenty of shopping opportunities, everything from food and art to independent shops and everything in between. Don’t hesitate to spend your time strolling down the street just window shopping or taking in the atmosphere. Beautiful architecture lines the streets. This is a true look into the real Amsterdam.

Picturesque, the Amsterdam you came to see. The Jordaan is the best part of Central Amsterdam. While most visitors spent there time in and around Dam Square, Red Light District, etc I felt as if I had this place between myself and the locals. You do not need a map, just wonder the streets, visit the small cafes and eat in the local restaurants. The architecture is what you would expect but with the never ending canals, bridges and small, quaint side streets it is a wonderful area.
A part to dream. we have dreamed during this visit : we would like to live there ! this makes us to dream...We have walk a long time in the small streets...

creativity in every niche. the combination of shops, cafés, art, restaurants...things and places you don't expect or haven't thought of...with the historic atmosphere of the buildings...you need to experience it :)
A village within the city. A great area - like a village within the city. Close to everything but quiet. Part of the old area of Amsterdam and very picturesque
Great neighborhood. Great neighborhood to walk. Safe with great views. Would have loved to spend more time here. Will definitely go back and enjoy when the weather is more warmer.
Charming Section of Town. I always visit the Jordaan when it Amsterdam as it has so much character as well as interesting cafés, bars and restaurants. The Pianola Museum is well worth a visit.
Jordaan is best part of Amsterdam. Beautiful. Shops, cafes, restaurants all around. Quiet too... Away from the more touristy and red-light districts, although easy to walk to those places if desired.

Nice Clean Neighborhood. Nice Cheese Museum
Nice Small Restaurants
Nice to walk around.
Beautiful old Coffee/Tea Restaurants.

Wonderful place for a walk and some photos. It is really beautiful here, and a good place to get all those Amsterdam photos you'll want to take home with you. Gorgeous canals and houses and lots of sweet cafes and shops if you have time to linger.
Love walking through the Jordaan. Wonderful atmosphere, great weekend away absorbing the amsterdam culture - everything is accessible, within walking distance and compact

Quaint, picturesque area of Amsterdam Centrum. The Jordaan is an area on the fringe of central Amsterdam that is well worth a stroll around. It feautures picturesque buildings, many restaurants and bars, and a huge variety of shops, many of which deal in arts and crafts, antiques and even second hand clothing. The Jordaan abuts (in part) the Nine Streets area, so there's little extra effort involved in strolling a bit further. It's worth the effort.

Great neighborhood. This is a great place to just walk around and absorb Amsterdam, especially if you're on a canal boat tour. Just get off at the Anne Frank House and wander around, stopping into one of the dozens of authentic Dutch coffee shops or local restaurants
people watching paradise. Great neighborhood to get lost in! We spent a lovely day just wandering around, stopping at cafes and watching the world go by.

Away from the tourists, a bit!. Having spent most of our previous visits in the Leidseplein district, we found the Jordaan to be much more interesting and atmospheric. There are great little shops, that give you the impression you are genuinely in the local community - bike repairs, bakeries, small cafes, craft jewellers, etc.

A nice place to stroll. We were told that this is the 'it' place to live in Amsterdam, and it definitely has charm. It's a nice place to stroll for an hour or so, with lots of little shops and places to grab a bite to eat.

Just wander. This area is full of small shop, fashion, art and small eateries and bars. Just wander from place to place, stopping occasionally to to drop in for breakfast, brunch, lunch, drinks or dinner. You are spoiled for choice in this area and most are good value and quality.

Picturesque. The Jordaan is the most picturesque neighbourhood in Amsterdam that I have seen. It has super cute small cafes and bars along the canal. The best way to explore the Jordaan is by cycle. Makes you want to live there.

The most spectacular place to walk around. This district of Amsterdam is one of the most beautiful places to go for a walk in Amsterdam, it is cozy, charming, and you can see the day by day of people in Amsterdam.

Carming, charming, charming!. We rented an apartment in The Jordaan for a week and enjoyed every bit of it! It is such a lively place and can be explored endlessly. We bough breakfast for a baker across the street and it was such a simple pleasure! I remember walking into an old-fashioned corner candy store and was taken back to my childhood! Young school kids were flocking into it and choosing from jars and jars of different candy stacked high to the ceiling! The whole area is charming and full of surprises like this.

Exemplary Look of Amsterdam. This area is exemplary look of Amsterdam. Trees lining along the canal and Dutch-style houses, cobbled streets crisscrossing narrow alleys, and a lot of design boutiques, cafes and restaurants. Quiet yet lively and fun in its own way.

Great for wandering. Fantastic district of Amsterdam if you're there to soak up the architecture and atmosphere. Lovely old houses, beautiful canals and lots of interesting places to dip in and out of.

The best experience in Amsterdam. Walking through this neighborhood is an endless pleasure ... a huge variety of amazing houses , art galleries, small 'brown' bars and, last but not least, ....... a sweet honey stroopwafel at a bakery facing a canal.Don’t miss a walk in the “nine streets” district, one of the city’s most picturesque shopping areas!

Lovely Neighborhood. Lovely neighborhood to stroll though and find a cafe to enjoy a meal. Within a short walk from the Anne Frank House. We found a grocery store here - Jumbo. A great grocery store if you are looking for snacks or food cheaper than what you can find in convenience stores. Also a nice selection of Danish snacks to take home for gifts. Great pricing on Stroopwaffles (8 individually wrapped for Euro 1.75).

We lived here. I like everything about the district. Both very quiet and comfortable and practically in the center of the city. Close to all major attractions and at the same time full of authentic Amsterdam chic.

Fascinating area. This is a fascinating area to wander through, lying along the main canals to the immediate east of the centre. The streets are narrow, the pavements even more so, and there are bridges over the canals. So you have to watch where you are walking - not least to avoid being run down by a bicycle or falling over a group parked at some corner! But it's all part of a very vibrant area. The area is home to a number of excellent restaurants and cafes and to some interesting shops - we ate there one evening and bought some good items produced by local craftspeople. There are several "hofie", hidden courtyards with almshouses, some quite old and all very peaceful. Unless you have endless time, it's worth carrying a guidebook or map with walk routes in it so that you can cover some of the best streets andfind cafes, shops and "hofie".

Best place to shop and enjoy Amsterdam. Jordaan is very interesting with its narrow alleys and the various spread of restaurants and pubs and coupled with the local Amsterdam crowd, this place gives you the best option to the see the real Amsterdam unravel in front of you. The whole Jordaan along the canal looks beautiful and breathtaking added with the charm of Village, cobbled streets and the lively atmosphere. Jordaan is the best possible destination in Amsterdam where you eat, dine, wine and shop in full glory and that too within a nice budget and experience. Do try out the small cafes around which surprises you. The place has a very unique character and has to be visited for that alone.

best area in amsterdam. I lived in the Jordaan for two years and it was a great experience. If you are visiting or staying in Amsterdam for the first time spend some time here, the charm of the canals, the canal houses and the streets is wonderful and there is a great selection of places to eat, drink and shop
Very cool. Search for the cheeseland shop, its great ! Very nice area! Recommended, dont use cars, use bikes or go by foot. Its is a beutiful area

The village within the city. De Jordaan is like a village within the city of Amsterdam.
